critique: This executive order promotes the use of alternative fueled vehicles within the federal government. It aims to reduce pollution, stimulate domestic economic activity, and utilize domestic fuel sources. It mandates that federal agencies exceed the alternative fueled vehicle purchase requirements set by the Energy Policy Act of 1992. The order also establishes a Federal Fleet Conversion Task Force to advise on implementation. It encourages cooperation with industry and state/local authorities on refueling capabilities. The order does not directly address immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. It could be seen as slightly liberal due to its environmental focus and government intervention in promoting alternative fuels. It also expands executive power slightly through the creation of the task force and mandates for agencies.
